PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Second Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [11th June, 1990],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Lew Syn Pau].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Hong Hai (Bedok GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion.

    Sir, I am gratified that the largest part of the President's Address was devoted to social issues. To my mind, these issues in the long run take precedence over all others. They will determine our viability as a nation.

    There is an old Russian saying that has a special meaning for me as a Singaporean. It says that the supreme punishment you can inflict on a Russian is to exile him from his country, his "Mother Russia" as they call it. To exile him is to cut him off from his spiritual roots. It is a fate more painful than death.

Column: 114



    Sir, would Singaporeans feel the same way about being exiled? Today, many Singaporeans exile themselves: they emigrate. Yet life in Singapore has never been so good. Last week, the First Deputy Prime Minister opened an exhibition designed to excite Singaporeans with the prospect of a gleaming high-technology city where everything works, and works efficiently. The image of the year 2000 is indeed impressive and worth striving for.

    But will this Singapore be the motherland to Singaporeans that Mother Russia was to the Russians? Will it be enough to stop Singaporeans from leaving? I wish I could say that it will be, but I am not sure.

    The President has spoken of "new challenges to inspire our people." In my humble view, there is an old challenge that we have tried to meet but not yet won. It remains our most important challenge. It is the challenge of our people coming together as a nation, sinking our roots here so deep that they would not be tempted away by cheaper housing and better cars in Australia, or bigger salaries in America, or less stress in Canada, or more liberal personal freedom in the United Kingdom.

    Sir, what will hold Singaporeans here? I have had occasion to talk to Singaporeans who recently emigrated, or who returned from long assignments abroad. I asked them: What did you miss from Singapore? They did not miss the Shenton Way skyline. Hong Kong and New York have better skylines. They did not miss the shops in Orchard Road. Tokyo and London have better shopping. Nor did they miss our super-efficient MRT or beautiful airport. Surprisingly, they missed the seemingly little things in life. Forgive me if I sound a little frivolous, but I think the person who summed it up best said to me, "I miss the Singapore char kway teow."

    Sir, at last year's National Day rally, our Prime Minister was moved by the bespectacled young man who said that he would not leave Singapore because this was the place he called home. What makes a man love his country and call it home? I cannot be certain what it is, in the case of Singapore. But I think I know what it is not. It is not the legendary cleanliness of our streets, or the 8% growth rate of the 1990s,

Column: 115

or the quality of our public housing. All these are strong pull factors, to be sure. But gleaming towers, productive factories, efficient communications and streets that are safe to walk are important mainly to our viability as an economy. They do not make a nation. For that, we have to look beyond.

    Sir, I have a vague notion that what will help us to coalesce as a nation has something to do with the seemingly little things in life: having a good laugh with your school friends, a glass of beer late at night in Bugis Street (the old Bugis Street), sitting on a hard stool smothered in smoke at the Satay Club, drowning in the Kallang roar when Fandi scored a goal, listening to a tale on Rediffusion by Lay Tai Soh, jostling with the crowds in Chinatown on Chinese New Year's eve, and not to forget, watching the Prime Minister mesmerise his audience with unending anecdotes at National Day rallies. Such are the little things that make Singapore great for Singaporeans.

    Sir, I hope that we never forget that a great nation is made up not just of high ideals or lofty ideology, but also of small traditions and shared experiences: the sights, the smells and the sounds that make up our memories, our loves, our friendships, our disappointments, and our triumphs.

    I am reminded of lines from the English poet, William Wordsworth, as he recollects his early childhood:

    'Thanks to the human heart by which we live,

    Thanks to its tenderness, its joys and fears,

    To me the meanest flower that blows can give

    Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears.'

    Sir, Singaporeans too have their thoughts and their tears. We have some history, traditions and the many small things that bind in some mysterious fashion the hearts of the people to this place.

    In our haste to reach the ranks of the developed nations, we have sometimes cast aside buildings, places, fragile traditions and old practices that collectively form our roots and heritage. I am greatly

Column: 116

heartened that the Urban Redevelopment Authority has in recent years paid increasing attention to the preservation of buildings of historical significance and tried to retain the character of places like Chinatown, Little India and Geylang Serai. We did it partly for commercial reasons, to make this place more interesting for tourists. But to me, the more important consideration is that they are part of the character and spirit of the nation.

    Sir, buildings and monuments are not enough. We must nurture great literature, art and drama. We must create room for charismatic people, for colourful personalities, for men with passion and purpose. The nation needs more heroes, people we admire and idolise - great writers, movie stars, television personalities, sportsmen, statesmen and philosophers. People of whom we can tell our grandchildren, people who will move on to become the subjects of literature and legend in succeeding generations. Heroes form the rallying points of a nation's psyche. They create pride and identity in a nation. They forge this indescribable bond amongst people, a bond that makes them a people.

    There is a Japanese saying that the nail that sticks out must be hammered down. We cannot afford to do this in Singapore. We already have too few heroes. We must redress this shortcoming. This is the challenge for the rest of this decade and beyond for our Government, for our captains of the media, and for the leaders of our cultural and community organisations. I hope, Sir, that they will not fail us.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion moved by the Member for Tanglin in thanking the President for his Speech delivered on 7th June, 1990.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there can be only a few governments in the world with such an overwhelming majority of seats in Parliament that pay this much attention to the needs of its people. In Singapore, democracy has a history of only a quarter of a century but we have seen ample proof of the sincerity of this Government, its willingness to subject itself to scrutiny, to

Column: 117

fire retro-rockets for mid-course corrections and even to admit publicly that not all of its policies have brought the desired benefits.

    I have over the years had the opportunity to meet and discuss with parliamentarians from other democracies their systems and ours. Often I have been asked if we, the PAP MPs, really represented in Parliament all the diverse views of our citizens considering that all but one seat belong to the ruling Party. I have never been at a loss to explain the duties and functions of the PAP Backbenchers. I could sincerely say that it was our duty to represent all citizens of our constituencies even those who voted against us.

    Sir, I can point to one other premise to explain how the ruling Party govern Singapore. The very fact that we are now debating the Presidential Address after Parliament was prorogued a few months ago is ample testimony of the Government's commitment to its people. Here is a Government that asks itself if its policies and directions are heading the right way. It asks if more could and can be done. It seeks clarification on a number of issues. It invites the widest possible discussion on national issues. It re-examines past policies and it checks if new ones are really all that beneficial.

    Sir, before the end of this session we will have a new Prime Minister who has proclaimed his desire to prorogue Parliament yearly to take stock of his Government's progress. Do we need any further demonstration of commitment? Some of our critics who have labelled us as being over-governed may still mutter that this is not enough. But I do not believe that the majority of Singaporeans can ever question the sincerity and desire of this Government to create an even bigger cake for its citizens and to raise living standards for all.

    What more can we do? There are obviously new challenges in the horizon. Among the more pressing is that related to the poor in our communities. We cannot deny that there are some who find it difficult to make ends meet to pay for the education of their children and even to meet utility bills. I am glad to note that the

Column: 118

Government gives attention to this aspect and pledges, as set out in the Presidential Address, to "lighten the burden of bringing up their children". I also think it is a bold step to commit the Government to "increase their assets".

    While the Government may already have a scheme worked out, may I, Mr Speaker, suggest that the Government consider a lower CPF rate for those earning $500 and below and less school fees for those children whose parents fall in this category. Statistics show that only a small percentage of our citizens falls into this category of the really low income group. For that reason, I do not believe that getting employers to pay the major portion of the CPF contribution is going to substantially increase the cost of doing business. In these exceptional cases, the employer should pay the present rate of 23% and the employee pays only 15%. That would be one way to "increase their assets".

    Upgrading of HDB flats, in a manner, also increases the assets of the owners. However, it is of little consequence to the owner to realise that his property is now worth, say, $100,000. He would have to sell his property to claim this asset. A roof over his head is his prime consideration and not the intangible worth of his house.

    I concede that the Ministry of Community Development has recently increased its welfare payment scheme. It is appreciated, but it is only a small measure. I am not calling for more hand-outs but perhaps a proper study and evaluation to determine who falls into this extremely low income group. There must be a basket of measures to help them. This can include lesser rentals, no income tax, less PUB charges, grants for school fees, subsidized meals and hospitalisation. I think this will be among the challenges that we will have to face as Singapore heads towards the next century.

    We must not allow some of our citizens to be deprived of the overall growth and progress of the country. In that respect, I see the introduction of the family services centres (FSC) as an important element in uplifting the quality of life in our communities. MCD has again taken the lead in

Column: 119

creating the conditions for such family service centres to be set up in the various parts of the country. I am happy to state that Telok Blangah expects to have such a centre in operation before the end of the year. We believe that the FSC will provide an extremely useful service, especially since it is community-orientated. We have planned and mapped our strategy so well. Let us not neglect this very small but significant group of Singaporeans.

    However, in setting up FSCs, there are numerous financial problems to be overcome. While MCD grants a sum that is equivalent to 50% of the start-up and operational costs, this is too little. After all, the FSCs are part of an essential service to the poor and to those who need the specialized service provided by the centres. Without greater funding, there is too much pressure on the operators of FSCs. I accept the fact that community leaders must attempt to raise part of the fund to run the centres. But I think it places too much of a burden on them to first serve in their various capacities in the FSCs and then also to be expected to organize schemes to raise the necessary fund.

    I must also point out that not all corporate organisations are forthcoming in their pledges of financial support. My own experience has been somewhat disappointing in that our appeals to the various foundations and corporate citizens for such funds for the Telok Blangah FSC has met with little success. Perhaps it is because I am not too familiar with the big boys, but whatever happens, I am committed to setting up the FSC in Telok Blangah. I would like to thank the Minister for Community Development and his Ministry for the kind support he has shown us with the allocation of an additional grant. And the other two responses have come from the 25th Anniversary Fund Committee and the PAP Foundation. Under these circumstances, I urge MCD to consider providing more funds to the FSC scheme.

    One other subject of importance which I would like to touch upon relates to the transition of leadership. I can think of no

Column: 120

better tribute to the Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, than to state that he has paved the way for his successor to take over the reins of Government. This renewal process has seen Singapore benefit from the infusion of new blood, great talents, and dedicated men and women. It has indeed been visionary of the leaders of the earlier generation to have themselves succeeded by the younger generation.

    While the top leadership has taken this renewal process seriously, it is my hope that fresh blood can be injected into the grassroots organisations as well. The cue must be taken from the Prime Minister and the First Deputy Prime Minister who have carefully over a number of years introduced younger leaders into Parliament. It would indeed be a shame if our grassroots organisations, like the CCCs, RCs and CCMCs, cannot find new faces to bolster their ranks. Let us not neglect or fail. The young must come forth and serve our nation.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I rise to support the motion in the name of the hon. Member for Tanglin to thank the President for his Speech made at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.

    In the President's Address, it was stated that the Government's programme is to create a better life for all Singaporeans. This proclamation of intention is one thing but, in reality, is the Government creating a better life for all Singaporeans? I do not think so. Singaporeans have to pay more for new cars. New car prices have shot up by at least 30% or more, not from January 1989, but from January of this year. Tuition fees of independent schools have been increased by ten times; hospitals fees have been raised, as one hon. Member yesterday stated, to a level when it can bankrupt retirees who are unfortunate to fall sick and have been warded in hospitals. Rentals of both commercial as well as private properties have all gone up. This has created problems for our local businessmen. HDB commercial property rentals are also not cheap. They can never be cheap because of the tender system. Local Singaporeans have to work very hard to pay for their high rentals. I often

Column: 121

hear local shopkeepers complain, "I am working only for the landlord."

    During my visits to the HDB flats, I noticed that many working couples do not come home until about 10.00 o'clock in the night. When I asked them for the reason, they say they are at their business. Long working hours appear to be the norm for many Singaporeans who run their own businesses. Are these people better off? The answer is obviously no. Most Singaporeans who run their own businesses have to work long hours from early morning to late at night, day-in and day-out, in order just to make a living. Many Chinese who run their own businesses have only their holidays once a year during the Chinese New Year. These are the self-employed small businessmen and they do not have CPF to their credit. For them, they cannot afford to fall ill. Their children have problems too, as both parents are out working all day and no one to look after them when they return from school. The Government levy on foreign maids is exorbitant and these parents cannot afford to engage them. For the majority of Singaporeans, their lives have not improved since the last session of Parliament. The extra costs they have to pay are all Government initiated.

    Has our education system improved? I say it is still very unsatisfactory. It is flawed. My reasons for saying so are as follows: Firstly, our local schools, except the independent schools, are over-crowded. Secondly, there is no compulsory education. Thirdly, our schools are examination-orientated. Fourthly, our school curricula are too over-loaded. Fifthly, there is still streaming in Primary 3 and Primary 6 levels. These problems are not new. I have spoken about them at one time or other in public since 1984. Except for the independent schools, our school is not getting better. An enrolment of 40 pupils in the class is definitely too large. A teacher can never teach effectively in such a class size. The teacher will not be able to give individual attention to all pupils. In fact, it was reported that almost every child in Primary 6 has a private tutor to coach him or her outside school hours. This is an indictment on our school system.

Column: 122



    It is well known that the second language is a problem to many pupils. Why is this so? This is not because our pupils cannot cope with their mother tongue but because there is no effective teaching in an overcrowded classroom. If our class size is small, I am certain our pupils have no difficulty mastering the mother tongue as the teacher can give individual attention to the weaker students. When the class is large, it also inhibits the promotion of creativity in the pupils. Creativity can only come if there is an interaction between the teacher and the pupils. When the class enrolment is too large, it makes it impossible for an interaction between the students and the teachers.

    In Japan, Taiwan and South Korea, there is compulsory education there in varying number of years. In Singapore today, we still do not have compulsory education. Compulsory education is good. This is to ensure that no child misses out on his or her schooling. I would suggest that for a start the Government should immediately legislate to make compulsory education for every child for eight years from age six years and eventually to increase the period to 10 years.

    Our school children in their school career are taking more official examinations than their Japanese or European counterparts. Children should not be made to sit common examinations when they are still in their primary level because their brains have still not fully matured. The late developers will be penalised irreparably if they are made to sit qualifying examinations at that tender age and fail. Young children are very sensitive, and once they are branded failures, through no fault of theirs, that stigma may remain with them for the rest of their lives. Psychologically, some people may not be able to shake off the traumas of early failures. And although in their later years when their brains have fully developed, they are still unable to make a success of their lives. Therefore, a good enlightened education system is important, if we truly want to develop the talent of all Singaporeans to the fullest.

    Another area of complaint is the heavy workload imposed on our school children,

Column: 123

especially those who are still in the primary schools. Parents have moaned that their children appear to have no time for anything else. At the primary level, children must be taught to enjoy schooling and enjoy learning. When too much work is given to young children, the majority of them may not be able to cope with it. Their interest in learning may be stifled for good. How then can we develop their talent to the fullest under such a warped education system?

    Now, about the library which I proposed to set up at Potong Pasir. If the Government is sincere in what it says and wants to help Singaporeans to improve themselves educationally, why then it refuses the people of Potong Pasir to set up a neighbourhood library? A library is a useful educational tool, especially one that is easily accessible to the people. The Government should discard its small-mindedness and allow the Opposition to initiate projects which are good for Singaporeans. I think this is an important issue. This is an appropriate time perhaps for the Government to recognise that the Opposition has a place in the political life of Singapore. The Opposition is a force for the good of Singapore. It provides a stimulus to the ruling Party. Open the doors to the Opposition, allow it to compete with the PAP to improve Singapore!

    When the Prime Minister was in London, he challenged the British journalist, who was a critic of his domestic policies, to interview him over British television, so as to give the Prime Minister a chance to rebut all the allegations made against him. But the said journalist refused to take up the offer. Similarly, I am now challenging the Government. I hope that the Government will not refuse this challenge. I am challenging the Government to come out openly and say that there is a place for the Opposition in Parliament in our Singapore way of life and allow the Opposition to legitimately compete with the PAP to do good for Singapore.

    At one time, the Government had even refused the Opposition to plant a single tree at Potong Pasir. I am glad to note that

Column: 124

the Government has passed that infantile stage. At the last Tree Planting Day, I had helped to plant several fruit trees at Potong Pasir.

    Of course, there is still now the problem of the library. I am confident that the Government will sooner or later see its folly and allow the neighbourhood library to be set up at Potong Pasir.

    Then, of course, there is the community centre. The Opposition, after more than five years in office at that constituency, is still denied access to it. I have read in the newspapers that certain PAP constituencies have won certain awards. How can it be said that the Marine Parade Community Centre or the Braddell Heights Community Centre has won the best run Community Centre or that it has the best cultural programmes respectively, when the Opposition is not allowed to compete in those competitions? Is the PAP afraid that the Potong Pasir Community Centre under the charge of the Opposition will sweep all prizes and be known throughout Singapore as the best run Community Centre?

    I have said that I would like to make Potong Pasir a model constituency. How can I do it if my hands are tied? Why is the Government so afraid of competition? The Government should stop putting obstacles in the way of the Opposition. Allow the Opposition access to information, allow the Opposition to take part in the national life of Singapore, allow the Opposition to debate over TV and radio on important national issues! The hon. Member for Fengshan said yesterday that the Government has done away with "wayang kulit" and "shadow boxing". I say this is not true. They have not been done away with. They are still very much intact.

    There cannot be participatory democracy if the Opposition does not play a major role in our national affairs. It must never be forgotten that the Opposition has about 40% of the total votes cast at the last general elections. The voice of the 40% of Singaporeans should not be silenced, should not be muted; it must he heard, otherwise all this so-called consultative style of the Government is nothing but a sham. The people of Singapore can very quickly see through the tricks of the

Column: 125

Government, the stage-managed feedback sessions during the ministerial walkabout and on television. As long as the Opposition is not represented on these public programmes, the feedback cannot be complete, because 40% of Singaporeans are not represented. The format of the Select Committee to gather feedback should also be altered. The Opposition must always be included in public hearings and the final report should not just comprise the Chairman's report but also include dissenting views of the Opposition.

    Next, I come to the 35 billion dollar issue. I am referring to the Elected President. He shall be given veto powers on how our national savings to be spent and also powers to appoint key civil servants. As the President in his Address said: This is "a major modification to our constitution." This change in our Constitution will affect the very foundation of our present parliamentary democracy. The Elected President can overrule Parliament, the supreme body of our land which represents the will of the whole population of Singapore. In effect, the Elected President can go against the will of the people of Singapore. In plain language, he has dictatorial powers. The sad thing is that once he is put in power, the Elected President virtually cannot be removed. The Elected President has also powers to appoint key civil servants. These top key civil servants will naturally be beholden to the President. If the top key civil servants are loyal to the President, would it not be difficult for the Prime Minister, who is the Chief Executive of the land, to govern the country? These important questions must be answered.

    In view of the fact that the introduction of an Elected President is a major modification to our Constitution, it is only right that there should be a national referendum over it. The PAP does not really have the whole electorate with it on this issue. It must be remembered that nearly 40% of our voters cast their votes against the issue of the Elected President.

    As regards the issue of Malay rights to free tertiary education, my feedback is that the majority of Malays are unhappy with it. They view it as a constitutional issue and not as a removal of rights to hand out to

Column: 126

them. Article 152 of the Constitution, inter alia, states quite clearly that the Government recognises the special position of the Malays, who are the indigenous people of Singapore, and that it shall, amongst other things, support the educational interest of the Malays. Free education to the Malays has been part of our life since the colonial time.

    The PAP Government took office in 1959 and later on we became independent in 1965. Throughout this period up to the present day, the Malays in Singapore have enjoyed free education up to tertiary levels. In other words, there is implementation of this part of our Constitution by the Government. And in accordance with the British constitutional law which we inherit, the carrying out of that part of the Constitution over time has made it become part of the Constitution by convention and practice. Therefore, it would appear that the Government's attempt to take away free education of the Malays is unconstitutional. It is a breach against well-established convention of the Constitution. I think this is the main complaint of the Malays - a deprivation of their established constitutional rights.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Member for Tanglin's motion in thanking the President for delivering the Speech in the House. Today, I would like to make use of this opportunity to talk on the following issues, including education, culture, the poor families, and the participatory type of government.

    Let me touch on education first. The President in his Address pointed out that in the next few years the Government will continue to emphasise education by strengthening primary education and providing a more flexible education system with more options for the parents and pupils.
